Ian,

After reading most of the article (I skimmed some), I thought it was interesting.  Ultimately,
though, from what I read he is using a purely boolean approach to his activation mechanism (below
< 2 does not fire, > 1 does fire).  Without smooth activation functions, it means the evolved
network by its nature must then create smoothness where it is needed IN THE CONNECTIVITY.  That
seems very inefficient.

It is an interesting experiment.  I would have to see it perform over the long term to be
convinced the results were equavalent to using a smooth activation functions (i.e. sigmoidal).  I
just don't think they are.  Human distinctions in reality of fuzzy.  Formal logic is just a small
subset of human intelligence.  And very few humans use formal logic.  And a pretty large number of
these produce "valuable" solutions to problems.

Then the guy kind of lost me with his whole "Terran/Artilect" discussion at the end.  I was not
prepared for that.  I then became all that much more suspicious he is just another "over-the-top
dreamer", scaling up a very simple view of logic as the basis for "artificial intelligence" - a
way over-abused term.  :^)


Jim
